value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="ms" place="margin">34</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are all 
            <choice>
              <sic>contrbutions</sic>
              <corr>contributions</corr>
            </choice> to our knowledge</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of what <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakespre</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> looked like, if you see him through</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a certain 
            <choice>
              <sic>visoon</sic>
              <corr>vision</corr>
            </choice>. But there always remains</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">something further. It is this that lures the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reader 
            <choice>
              <sic>Abd</sic>
              <corr>and</corr>
            </choice> it is this quality that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">finally eludes us. gives him his perpetual vitality,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he 
            <choice>
              <sic>ecites</sic>
              <corr>excites</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>perp tual</sic>
              <corr>perpetual</corr>
            </choice> curiosity. He does not as so many</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">writers feed momentary 
            <choice>
              <sic>appettites</sic>
              <corr>appetites</corr>
            </choice>. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>resder</sic>
              <corr>reader</corr>
            </choice> who has a dash</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the writer in him, seeks out certain styles; certain</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">forms. But 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakespere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> has 
            <choice>
              <sic>nosuch</sic>
              <corr>no such</corr>
            </choice> appeal to the reader-writer.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">His styles are too 
            <choice>
              <sic>innumerabel</sic>
              <corr>innumerable</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>Perhpas</sic>
              <corr>Perhaps</corr>
            </choice> then he is chiefly</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">used for more general 
            <choice>
              <sic>piposes</sic>
              <corr>purposes</corr>
            </choice>--when the ink has gone dry</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">upon the pen to revive the sense of 
            <choice>
              <sic>langauge</sic>
              <corr>language</corr>
            </choice>; or to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">testify, when words seem 
            <choice>
              <sic>motiinless</sic>
              <corr>motionless</corr>
            </choice>, to the enormous</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">possibilities of speed. One reading always supersedes another</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Thus the 
            <choice>
              <sic>trueest</sic>
              <corr>truest</corr>
            </choice> account of reading 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakespere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> would be</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not to write a book with a beginning middle and end;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but to collect notes, without trying to make them</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">consistent.</l>
